title: Review: Oupa – Forget
content:
Just over six months ago I was sent a handful of tracks composed by Yuck frontman Daniel Blumberg.

Not being a particularly huge fan of the brash, grating sound created by the London four piece, it was with considerable caution that I approached The Weakend EP, tagged under the artist name Yu(c)k. By the end of opening track Daughter, I was already well and truly sold.

Gone are the vivacious guitars and shameless Sonic Youth impressions, instead replaced by elegant piano sections and Blumberg’s heavenly vocals. Now going under the name Oupa, new seven track release Forget continues in a similar vein, emotionally haunting and movingly poignant. The title track which was made available around the same time as the original EP is blissfully self-aware and enchantingly regretfully. The vocal delivery and productions hark back to Bon Iver’s For Emma, For Ever Ago, constantly altering in intonation and pitch, allowing the track to flow seamlessly. Blumberg almost weeps ‘I’ll be natural, no you can’t forget me now’, it would take an extremely cold heart to deny the sincerity in Oupa’s work.

As an entirety, the release is dominated by melancholic piano sections, verging upon driving Forget into emotional overload, however there is enough variation in the songwriting to prevent this becoming an inevitability. Opener Driving is drenched in searingly honest regret; ‘I have never seen a face, that hit me so hard, with all it’s grace’, bemoans Blumberg joylessly. Those whom have been following the progress of CitR favourite Youth Lagoon, will be able to hear the comparisons, namely in the wistful tone of the music.  Both excel in transferring emotional complexities from the fragmented mind to musical composition, whilst maintaining a relatable, scrupulous appreciation  for the listener.

New Home feels like Bowie performing Beatles tracks whilst on antidepressants; epic, honorable and truly veracious, one of the finest tracks Blumberg has written to date. Closing track Those Are The Senses is the most enduring of them all, coming in at just under eleven minutes, and featuring the song writing skills of Daniel’s brother Saul. A repetitive guitar section underpins the entire track, during which the vocal driven tension builds gradually to a divinely emotive, heart-breaking crescendo. Having never bought into Yuck’s music, it’s increasingly refreshing to hear a band member craft a work of art so utterly beautiful and startlingly different; staking a claim for the most transcendent release of the year. Forget is available on cassette and download via Boiled Egg, from here.
